subject: RE: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a thrown exception ?
msgSnippet: We have modified JUnit to count asserts, because we find that to be interesting data for metrics.  Therefore, since we are implying that something went wrong
messageBody:
We have modified JUnit to count asserts, because we find that to be
interesting data for metrics. Therefore, since we are implying that
something went wrong when it was supposed to, we do an assert to add to the
count.

> -----Original Message-----
> From: rainsber@... [mailto:rainsber@...]
> Sent: Monday, July 16, 2001 9:39 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] How do I implement a test case for a thrown
> exception ?
>
>
> assertTrue(true) is meaningless and confusing. By
> default, if you get to
> point X of a test, then all must be well so far,
> otherwise the next line
> will be "fail(...)". Don't write assertTrue(true). :)
>
> Let the framework communicate; it's a good one!
>

>
> If you want to eliminate the boolean, use your first
> example and do the
> assert in the catch block.
>
> public void test_00_isPartnerAssigned() {
>
> try {
>
> instancePartnerHierarchyWorker.isPartnerAssigned(null);
> fail("IllegalArgumentException should be thrown.");
>
> } catch (IllegalArgumentException iae) {
>
> assert(true);
>
> } catch (PartnerNotFoundException pnfe){
>
> fail("PartnerNotFoundException should not be
> thrown.");
>
> } catch (PersistenceException pe){
>
> fail("PersistenceException should not be thrown.");
> }
> }
>

> > --- Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@...> wrote:
> > > > The Junit.org site has an FAQ section
> > > > (http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/faq/faq.htm) with
> > the following
> > > > question: How do I implement a test case for a thrown
> > exception?
> > > >
> > > > The answer they give is not completely correct
> because it does
> > > not
> > > > account for the possiblility that another
> exception could be
> > > thrown.
> > >
> > > I think they assume that your method only throws one
> > exception. If
> > > your method throws more exceptions, you can use:
> > >
> > > // Test IllegalArgumentException is thrown when
> > partnerID is null.
> > > public void test_00_isPartnerAssigned() {
> > > try {
> > > boolean assignedStatus =
> > >
> instancePartnerHierarchyWorker.isPartnerAssigned(null);
> > > } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
> > > return;
> > > } catch (Exception e) {
> > > fail("IllegalArgumentException should have
> been thrown.");
> > > }
> > > fail("IllegalArgumentException should have
> been thrown.");
> > > }
